December 3, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

A full time caretaker is necessary at the Fairford Improved Day School. At the present time a caretaker is employed on part time at $25.00 per month. There is now only one teacher at the school, but the Department nurse makes the school her headquarters.

I understand that the nurse's livery account on the Fairford Reserve runs around $35.00 per month. This amount added to the $25.00 per month would allow a full time caretaker and also allow the nurse livery at any time. I beg to recommend that a full time caretaker be employed at a wage of $60.00 per month. This to include the driving of the Department at all times on the Fairford Reserve and the caretaking of the school on a full time basis.

J. Walter,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, Ontario,
December 7, 1946

Your File 50-11

The School Branch have referred your letter of December 3rd to this office and after discussing it we feel that it will be in order to arrange that the caretaking for the school and livery work for the nurse be done by the one man. You could forward these accounts on a monthly voucher and the School Branch will pay $25.00 and the Medical Branch $25.00 of the amount.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.,
Actg./Supt. Indian Health Services.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Dear Sir,

A few weeks ago I wrote you regarding money owing me for work done at Little Bank Indian School, also a refund of money paid out by me because of the maladministration of Agent Waite & farm instructor.

Yours truly,

SIR,

FUEL FOR SCHOOL—

NELSON HOUSE.

This is always a burning question amongst all the reserves in this Agency, some Indians will get wood for the school, while others will not. It was agreed that the sum of $1.00 should be retained at Treaty time from every able bodied Indian for $\frac{1}{2}$ a cord of stove wood. Money to be refunded on delivery of wood at the school. Dear sir,

I am in receipt of your letter regarding combining the Indian School here with the Public School. The present teacher is Mr Allan Burton to whom the salary should be paid. I presume two registers will have to be kept. Will you kindly request the Indian Agent at The Pas to see that the Moose Lake Band supply half the wood required for use at the school?

Sir,—
I have the honor to report that when I visited the Chemawain Day School the teacher told me all the wood for the school had been hauled in from the bush by an Indian named John James Starr as no other person had a team of horses, and there was only one ox on the Reserve who was too old to work. The wood was cut free by the Indians, twenty cords in all, and the teacher asked me if I would apply for assistance to the Department to pay Starr for his work. I asked Starr what it was worth, but he said he had no idea, but would like to get 10 bushels of seed potatoes next spring if possible. Under the circumstances I beg to recommend to the Department that this be done.

Next season this will not be necessary as I understand that the estimates provide for a team of oxen at this point. The potatoes would not cost more than $15.00.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Sir;-

The teacher at the day school at Big Eddy, on the Pas Reserve, has asked me if the Department can make her an allowance for firewood, she requires five cords of short wood which would cost $25.00.

At the other schools in the district where we have men teachers they cut their own wood, but this teacher is an old lady who has no equipment for the work.

I have the privilege from some of the band to inform on some matters which they think is not right, first:

It's about wood paying if they don't put it at the school, now some has cut the wood and left it in the bush, they had no way of getting it to school. Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 48-128, dated the 16th ultimo, in connection with our voucher No. 306 amounting to $12.85 in favour of the Hudson's Bay Co., Winnipeg, for food used by the Split Lake Indians while cutting wood for the Split Lake School.

This wood was cut on the instructions and authority of Mr. S. Lovell, Indian agent. He told the Rev. G.J. Cowley he could issue some supplies to the Indians while they were cutting the wood.

Apparently a large number of the Indians took some part in this work and the food was used by the Indians who were doing the work. No record was kept of who was working or the quantity of wood cut, but I understand sufficient was cut and hauled to last the School all winter. It is obviously practically impossible to make out a pay-list when the work was done in this manner. Mr. Cowley has sent in a receipt signed by one of the councillors, which I am attaching here-to. Dear Sir:

In the list of graduates in the report which we are forwarding with this mail, James Taylor is listed. Dear Sir:

No doubt you have received my letter to the Dept. of Education of Manitoba, my letter dated November 28, 1941. In this letter of mine dated Nov. 28, 1941, I have suggest or request to get an Indian higher education, on which I am quite depending on the Indian Dept. The reason I happen to come to consider this is there is only an Indian in this World of ours don't seem to know enough of the present conditions. But I would suggest and think so, an Indian has got same amount of brains in his head as any other person - like Chinaman, Japanese Black man. Right today these different people of different Countries are doing fine - they run their own machinery and their Government, and I am sure they were taught how to run these things. I don't say an Indian should try to get to run his own Government, but to get him to help out his country more through his studies.

Like today for instance right at The Pas here Indian Boys tried to volunteer, but they come back almost for the same thing - not enough education - can't talk English or write English. They are healthy enough to be able to stand Army life, and of course there are others that are Medical unfit, to be in the Army.

Therefore, I would humbly ask the Indian Dept. to consider this for us, and help to make our beloved Canada a better Country, through giving us Indians more education. I had a talk with the Principal of Elkhorn Indian School about this matter, and I found out that M.S.C.C. had quite a lot to do with the Indian education, and I point out to him.

If it would be possible if the Indian Dept. and M.S.C.C. would give us a separate High School just for Indians alone, so I would be very much obliged. If the Indian Dept. would consider this for us; also I have brought this up before several Indian Dept. Officials such as Indian Agent of The Pas, Indian Agency, but no one seems to shake a leg. But the reason I quite determined to put this through direct to you. I think I got right to ask for this as I am one of them that try to do what the Indian Dept wants an Indian to do to send their children to School. Although it is a grier sometimes in my heart knowing my children are far away from home. But I would say I don't want to grieve for nothing. I would like to see my children to be somebody when they get through their studies. Not only my children but the whole Indian Race of Canada.

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received by the Department from John William Harris, who refers to himself as a member of The Pas Band.

You should inform Mr. Harris that his letter has been received by the Department but that his communication dated November 28, 1941, to which he refers, was not sent forward to this Branch.

It is somewhat difficult to learn from this letter what this Indian is actually advocating. The establishment of a high school for Indians would scarcely appear practicable, in view of the comparatively few Indian pupils who reach Grade 8. At schools where a certain percentage do reach Grade 8, provision is usually made for instruction in Grade 9. In addition to this, the Provincial Departments of Education provide high school instruction by correspondence. There is no reason why an ambitious pupil of The Pas Band should not take advantage of this offer. In any event, it is not at all likely that a high school for Indians will be established at any time in the immediate future.

Ottawa, January 26, 1946.

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Manitoba.

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to Indian children attending a Provincial white school at Thicket Portage.

I infer from the Secretary-Treasurer's letter that the cost will be approximately $10.00 Monthly for Indian children attending this school. This rate is a great deal higher than we have allowed white schools previously. This is due, no doubt, to the comparatively small attendance at the school. Is there no other White school in the vicinity that Indian children could attend? Incidentally, I would like to know if the Indian children who are attending or wish to attend reside on the Reserve or off the Reserve.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
The Pas, Manitoba,
January 29, 1946.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that this is the only school in the vicinity, and these children would have to go to that school, or lack education, as the boarding school is too full.

There is no Indian Reserve at Thicket Portage. The Indians residing there are living on registered trapping grounds from the Province of Manitoba, so they are permanent residents of this settlement.

Trusting this is the information you require, I am,

Your obedient servant,

S. Lovell,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Emile Hughes File 103-128 (E.1)

I am in receipt of your letter with regard to placing Emile Hughes in our school next term. While we have no objections at all to accepting this boy I would like to suggest that you place him in our Indian Residential School, Spanish, Ontario. Our course here is a matriculation course only. At our school at Spanish, besides the regular matriculation course each boy has an opportunity to learn several trades. The school is practically self-supporting and provides training in shoe-making, carpentry, tailoring, baking, cooking, farming in all its branches. The boy would also have an opportunity to obtain instruction in music.

For further information about the school at Spanish, please communicate with: Rev. J. R. Oliver, S.J., Indian Residential School, Spanish, Ont.

If, however, you prefer to send this boy here, please write again. This year the fee for board and tuition was $325, with laundry extra. Next term the fee will be raised somewhat, though I cannot quote the exact figure now.

Mr. B. Mary
Superintendent of Education
Ottawa Ont.

Dear Sir,

It seems that you did not receive my letter of Aug 24th. I was at Indian Lake, visiting my sister, when yours reached me. I immediately replied thanking you for the raise and accepting the salary indicated.

Again in Sept., I wrote to you in reply to your second letter. Regret to say that this one was
writing in a more familiar style and might have offended you. It was written when I was worrying myself sick of my adopted Emile Higher who was sent to (St Paul's) the Garnier School in Spanish Ont.

The boy's first letter was most pathetic and really he was shocked at the conditions of the place. He said that it reminded him of Dickens' selection "Oliver Twist". He is not very homesick but he is heart-broken because he wasn't sent to St Paul's. He had been working so hard to raise money for clothes also for a monthly allowance of five dollars.

Music is part of Emile and he taught himself a
$5 dollar guitar and a violin of $7. He plays both quite well, and he expected to get lessons, but he can't touch his instruments. They're locked up until Xmas. He hasn't played once on them since he got there.

He was supposed to learn a trade; instead he says they're digging a trench of $4 \times 2 \times 6$. He doesn't say what it is for. After all he's only fifteen years old and he went there for an education not to be a galley slave.

As far as school work is concerned he finds it very easy in grade II. It doesn't surprise me as he was very good last year.

Another thing, Mr.
Henry, the boy says he is not getting any mail from me. I can't understand that so I sent him a letter containing money which had registered also an insured parcel with some letters which some boys wrote to him. He got theirs but nothing from me.

I raised the kid just like a white boy, I liked him just like a son and I am so worried that I can't work properly. I started taking a correspondence course and found it interesting but for the last two weeks I haven't done a thing. I am afraid of freeze-up which means a long isolation.

The place was grossly misrepresented. Please, Mr. Henry transfer him to
St Paul's. We'll be so well there with my sisters to visit him once in a while.

One of them is Mrs Blackburn who was at Island Lake for many years; he'd be quite at home with her.

If you have children Mr. Hearty you must know how much one can suffer and worry for them.

If you want to see Emile's letters Mr. Low has two of them which I sent to him.

Yours truly,
Roland G. Launé
October 14, 1948.

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of the 7th instant and have noted your remarks regarding Emile Hughes.

We are unable to agree with the statements that the boy has made to you regarding the Spanish Indian Residential School. Officials of the Department and the Ontario Department of Education Officials visit this school frequently and all of them report that every possible opportunity is being given to the pupils attending this school.

In view of the very large expenditure that would be necessary if the boy was transferred to the St. Paul's College, Winnipeg, we are not prepared to make any change during the current academic year.

August 5th, 1946.

Mr. S. Lovell,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Dear Sir;

Enclosed please find a number of statements for various goods and services rendered.

When you were here at treaty time I assured you that all accounts for last year had been rendered to you, and so I believed. Yesterday I was checking over my accounts and I asked Tom if he knew any reason why these accounts had not been paid yet; it was then that he told me that he had typed out the statements in March and had put them in a cardboard box in my office for me to check over before mailing. Not knowing what was in this box, and believing that he had mailed the statements I did not enquire further until yesterday when I was making up the current statements.

I am sorry that this has happened, it was a mistake on my part that I did not make sure at the time that the job was completed and a mistake on his part in putting them in a box and caching them away instead of leaving them on my desk for checking.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Extract from letter from Mr. C.A.F. Clark dated 17th September, 1947. Original on 128-15-1

She (Miss Montgomery) wants the janitor allowance increased Ten dollars would be fair (she suggested twenty!). I explained that the pupils should be taught to keep the place clean and tidy (Miss M's difficulty!) but not as a punishment. The only paid duty might well be lighting (not tending) the fire. Our teachers must try to get more Indians to abandon the notion that the school is a necessary evil related to family allowances and such other windfalls as can be engineered.
Ottawa, September 30th, 1947.

Mr. Samuel Lovell, Indian Agent,
The Pas, Manitoba.

On the recommendation of Mr. Clark who recently visited the Big Eddy School, the Department has decided to allow the teacher an amount of $10.00 a month for janitor services, effective from September 1st, 1947.

Payment will be made quarterly on receipt from you of the usual voucher.

Miss Montgomery can then make her own arrangements for janitor services.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I have for answer your letter of December 21, with regard to these children.

Fortunately, the Indian Act is very clear in such cases. Section 14 reads as follows:

"Any Indian woman who marries any person other than an Indian, or a non-treaty Indian, shall cease to be an Indian in every respect within the meaning of this Act, except that she shall be entitled to share equally with the members of the band to which she formerly belonged, in the annual or semi-annual distribution of their annuities, interest moneys and rents........."

Therefore, the Regional Director of Family Allowances has acted quite correctly with regard to stopping the family allowances of these children. They are of non-Indian status and should attend your schools. In this regard you might be interested in the monthly report form now used in our Indian day schools. I

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re NAPOLEON PRINCE

On the tenth day of this month Napoleon Prince came to the school and asked to be allowed to return to High School. He also asked that he be allowed to reside at the school while attending High School.

I was puzzled over his return, because I had been led to believe that he left school last year at his own request, and with his father's consent. However, after questioning Napoleon pretty carefully, I became convinced that he did really wish to continue his education. His father has also been to see me and has assured me that it is his wish also.

I would have written you earlier about this matter, but felt that it was wise to try to get some more positive indication that Napoleon not only wished to continue his education, but had the will-power and stamina to start back to school, after being absent for over a year, and with several weeks of work to catch up on in all his classes.

He was allowed to start to High School on February 11th, and he has already shown good results. He is really applying himself. I understand that on his first test in French he had no mistakes. One evening last week I offered him the chance to attend a hockey game, but he preferred to continue working on his assignments in Mathematics and History. All this certainly seems to speak well for the boy's ability and interest in continuing his education.

I feel that I am now warranted to apply for the grant paid for High School students to be paid for Napoleon Prince, and to request that he be again admitted as a resident pupil to this school. I firmly believe that he will continue his education, at least to the completion of High School.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Principal

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re TUITION GRANT

I discovered during the past term that the grant of $7.50 monthly was insufficient to take care of the cost of maintaining a High School student. The cost per student of books, athletic and other fees, instruments, and necessary incidental expenses was in excess of $100.00 per student. I have requested the amount of $100.00 per student.

The two students who completed their respective years in Kenora High School during the 1948-49 term made quite decent marks. Orpha Mandamin completed Grade IX obtaining second class honours. Sam Kopinesse completed Grade X obtaining third class honours. Both these students wish to continue their studies. I recommend that they be allowed to do so.

This year we will be faced with a very acute problem - that of accommodating all our pupils. The fact that several of our pupils expect to be returning to attend High School makes this situation even more than usually difficult. Of course, if we are to assist our better pupils - those who have passed their Entrance requirements - to stay here while continuing to attend High School, some provision should be made for separate space for them for study. That is almost impossible in this building where every nook and cranny has already been put to some necessary use. For that very reason I am very anxious to make some arrangement for some of these High School students to board in Kenora while attending High School.

The lack of adequate space to provide for them in this school is a sufficient reason for considering this course of procedure. Added to that is another reason which carries even more weight. At about the age that these young people are ready to begin attending High School, it is very important that they begin to mix socially with white people. Also it is important that they escape from the "institutional" atmosphere which of necessity permeates a residential school. They need to be allowed more freedom than can be permitted in a residential school containing younger children who must for obvious reasons be subjected to pretty rigid discipline. I believe that this can best be done by allowing them to board in white homes.

In spite of the fact that my experience with this race has been very limited, I can claim to have some evidence to support the view stated above. During our holidays my wife and I took two pupils from this school with us. When we visited friends of ours they accompanied us. In less than a month the extent to which they had begun to lose the sense of inferiority, and had begun to speak freely among white people, was truly amazing.
If we are to arrange for some of these students to board in Kenora while attending High School, then we are going to require more than the amount of the regular per capita grant to maintain them. No student can board in Kenora today for much less than $12.00 per week.

I should very much like to arrange for a few of our students to board during the coming term. If it is felt that this is an experiment of doubtful value, may I suggest that I be authorized to make arrangements for not more than two of our pupils to board in Kenora this year. I have already discussed the possibility in one suitable home, but of course am unable to state definitely that there is a home available, until authorized to make necessary arrangements.

May I stress the necessity for giving this matter fair consideration. Even with much more space available than we have in this school, our High School students are not being given as good an opportunity to succeed as the average English-speaking student. They begin High School with many handicaps. If we are to expect them to succeed, then we must be prepared to make some additional expenditures. If our present students find things too difficult, we can hardly expect their followers to be enthusiastic.

Please give this matter the consideration which it seems to warrant.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Principal.
Kenora, August 9th, 1949

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re TUITION GRANT

A letter received from the Chief of the Education Division suggests that my letter to you dated Aug 8, 1949, has been misunderstood. If this misunderstanding is due to lack of clarity on my part, I regret it. I was trying to suggest a solution to a problem which will soon become acute here: that of accommodating all our pupils, including those attending High School. The point of my letter appears to have been lost almost entirely.

Mr. Phelan suggests no alternative but that of discharging High School students from this school. I feel certain that if he had grasped the problem presented in my letter, some more considerate suggestion would have been put forward. I am certain that Mr. Phelan is just as interested as you or I in endeavouring to raise the standard of education reached by our Indian young people. May I ask that the problem presented in my letter of Aug 8 (not inferences deduced therefrom) be given the consideration warranted.

If further reason is needed to support the suggestion put forward, may I venture to remind those concerned that a vast expenditure is involved in educating Indian children. If we are unable to meet the needs of those who are capable of continuing their education and wish to do so, then much of our work must be wasted. Surely we do not wish to educate them so far and then stop. Surely to do so would be to adopt a very short-sighted point of view. Even my own very limited experience with your Department has convinced me that it is a very real concern for the welfare of the Indian people. May I ask for more careful consideration of this problem.

Sincerely yours,

T.C. Ross
Principal.

We have your letter of October 4th, your file 129/25-8, enclosing a copy of a letter received from the Principal of the Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School with regard to Sammy Kopinesse and Orpha Mandamin, who are attending the Cecelia Jeffrey Residential School.

We have carefully noted the contents of both letters, and we have no doubt that Mr. Ross is interested in the welfare of the two pupils mentioned. I feel that you should assure him that Departmental officials are also interested.

We showed our interest in these two children by the instructions contained in the 2nd paragraph of official letter of September 9th to Mr. Ross. Our experience, covering many years, proves that when a residential school is situated close to a high school, the best possible manner of having the Indian children attend the high school, is to have them reside at the residential school and attend the high school as day pupils. By doing so, the Department is assured that their leisure hours will be properly spent, as they will then come under the supervision of the residential school staff.
We cannot agree with you or Mr. Ross that for the purpose of overcoming the inferiority complex of Indian children, it is necessary to have them board with white people. I might add that it would simply be impossible to handle the matter as suggested by Mr. Ross from a financial standpoint. We inferred this in our letter of September 9th, in which it was stated that either the children remained in the residential school and the school management drew the grant plus an additional amount of $75.00, or the children were discharged from the school.

It is hoped that Mr. Ross will see the necessity for close supervision of the children during their leisure hours, and carry out the wishes of the Department by having the children reside at the Cecelia Jeffrey School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Dear Mr. L'Heureux:

It is six years that I have been going to Juniorate St. John and enjoyed these years. I appreciate greatly the good the kind fathers of the Juniorate and those of Stronard have done to me. I appreciate you especially for paying my school at the Juniorate.

I do not think I will return to the Juniorate because the fathers, who always look for our good, have advised me not to, since they think that priesthood is not my vocation. I told them that I would like to continue my studies. They advised me to address myself to you since you are always looking for the good of the Indians.

Last June I wrote three examinations from the University of Ottawa. I received my results lately. Here they are: French 55, Latin 58 and 62 for Greek. I also wrote the examinations of the department of Alberta. I did not receive my results yet. I am in Grade II. I will be in Grade III next year.

If the department is willing to pay for my school next year, I would greatly appreciate it, because I would like to com-
time till my studies are completed. I will do my best to be worthy of it. I would like to take a course in engineering, but this idea may change.

I would be happy to continue my studies, if it were possible. For now, I am doing a little work here and there at the mission. I help the brother at the barn and do the work he gives me to do. I enjoy it, for it is not very hard.

Once more, I thank you very much for paying my school at the Juniorate.

Goodbye and thank you.

Gratefully yours,
Joseph Providence.

Grouard, Alberta

Dear Mr. Hoey:

This is just to tell you that our new building for the factory is still in process. The Indians here have the entire responsibility of the erection of this building. They have named a leader among themselves and the people deal entirely with him until the building is completed. It is not going as fast as I would like it to go, but we are working with the adults on the same principal as we were working with the children in the C.Y.C. They must take the initiative, the lead, and the responsibility. If we take into consideration, as it is so often said, that the Indians are children or minors, it is up to us to educate them into becoming adults. For this purpose, I know of no other method but to make them assume responsibilities. Really, they have been doing very well. The cellar 20 x 40 has been dug and cribbed. The logs for the building are all cut, partly hauled and peeled. They are now starting to hew them on 2 sides and soon they will be putting up the walls. They have also made cash donations towards the building.

I was just telling the Bishop today that I wish we could be building all the time this way. They work together, they take the leadership, the responsibilities, and through trial and error, they are receiving the most wonderful education that they could possibly receive. This is just the objective that I was trying to attain when I first spoke of industries. Seeing these results of which I was sure before we ever started, I hope we will continue to find projects for them that they may keep on working collectively.

I hope to be able to inform you before very long that our building is up. It would not be a monument suitable for the Ottawa city because I am afraid it is going to be a picture of primitive un-skilfulness. It will certainly be only a picture of the degree we have reached in the civilization of this population.

Thanking you kindly once again, I remain,

Yours truly,

P.S. The old pupils are on the war-path; they want Sr. Jean back here. They want to write the Mother General to this effect, begging her for the sake of this population, to bring Sr. Jean back to Grouard.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill,

Attached hereto please find letter from Peter Gresschuk, Solicitor of Edmonton, dated the 16th instant, re Paul Sound, a treaty Indian residing on a reserve near Kinuso, Alberta, who is desirous of sending his children who are 10 and 8 years respectively to the school in the town of Kinuso and he wishes to be advised as to whether it is possible for a treaty Indian to send his children to a town school.

The question submitted to the Department is difficult to answer and if answered at all must be in the broadest terms. An Indian living on the reserve is a denizen of the Province in which he resides and has all the rights and liabilities of a white person. There are, of course, definite restrictions under the Indian Act where an Indian is living within a reserve.

In so far as Paul Sound's children's school attendance is concerned it would seem that as he owns property in the town and it is assumed his taxes are paid, he should have the same school privileges as other property holders in the municipality. On the other hand it has been held in a British Columbia case that there is no duty cast upon a school board to receive within its schools children who are not resident within its own municipal district.

As the question Mr. Gresschuk asks is one that deals with Alberta law it is not felt that any information which we can give him would be very helpful other than the statement that an Indian within the Province has, for all practical purposes, the same rights as a white person.

Solicitor.

I have your letter of the 17th instant, referring to previous correspondence with reference to Indian children attending public schools. As a general rule the Department prefers having Indian children attend our own residential schools where they receive every possible care and attention, as well as a good education. For varied or serious reasons an Indian might be permitted to send his children to an outside school, but in all such cases we require a definite recommendation from the Indian Agent or the Inspector of Indian Agencies and in addition we would only allow such procedure on the distinct understanding that the children would attend the white school regularly. We have found in many cases that parents use the excuse of wishing to send their children to a white school simply to avoid sending them to any school. In other words, if we give our permission to send them to a white school some Indian parents enroll the child at the white school and the child seldom, if ever, attends.
If you have any requests by Indians residing on a reserve to send their children to a white school rather than to the Indian residential schools provided for them, you should submit all cases to this office, giving full particulars and at the same time making a recommendation. Our Public Works are not progressing nearly as fast as I would desire. They are putting up the rafters today. Fortunately we have had marvellous weather and the men were able to keep up the work. They have made many a white man lie in this that they kept going. I doubt however that we will be able to use the building before next Spring.

As regards this building which is to be our Factory, our Store, our Warehouse and all, it is considered here as a very large building. It is large for a log house and it rather embarrassed the contractors... hence the delay. So far, it has cost the people $875.00 which they have been able to raise in this pitiful settlement of Grouard. The revenues have come from the profits of their Co-operative ($500.00). The balance was procured by them and from them through donations, socials and bingos. We have our weekly meetings of the Co-operative in which they discuss their problems (Indian way) but which is left entirely to them to find the means and ways by which they are to complete the project they have undertaken with considerable interest. At every meeting I propose to put off the completion of the building till next Spring at which time we may have more funds, but I am voted down every time. And that is the way it goes. May I add that this has been entirely an Indian enterprise. I have permitted no White Man to build in at any time nor under any consideration. There were some who would have gladly helped and the Indians would have gladly accepted their services but I strictly refused. The Indians would have been glad to shun the responsibility of the project, though, just as children, they would have been sorry to see anyone else but themselves get the credit of the same. If Indians are Minors, as we so often say, it is our job to educate them to become adults...and it is great time that we do so. This education can only be given by giving them responsibilities. The work is not as good and it has cost us more...but a thousand dollars is not much in education, surely. It appears to me that we have always treated them like babies and...babies they have remained to this day. In any case, this project has worked wonders amongst them. It has given them a sense of pride, honesty and sociability. It has given them a common interest which they feel now will be kept up in this environment as it keeps on developing. It has done away with a lot of grumbling that is bound to spring from idle minds. The workers have been criticized publicly at our meetings, by their own people for being just what we think they are: too slow, too easy-going, too careless...and perhaps, not tops in their business. The workers themselves realize it now. They say: "if we were to start the building over again, we wouldn't do it that way or that...etc...etc." Yes, they have made mistakes...but White Men make mistakes also. In any case, they are quite happy about it all...and that's a lot.

We have no more funds however, and the workers will have to wait for their pay next Saturday. How is it going to turn out, I don't know. I really think they have been fleeced of all the pennies.
they had here in Grouard, so I don't know where the next funds are going to come from. It may be that finally we will have to stall the work till next Spring. I will certainly not allow them to take any more out of the Store. That is dangerously low as it is now. They spoke of borrowing some and I told them to go ahead if they wished but that they would have to back it up themselves staking their horses, wagons, houses etc., etc. They were not particularly fussy about doing that.

May I add that the Old Pupils are really the ones who are pushing this project. They see and say that their children may profit by it. That is quite a step. It also has given them an incentive to better their homes. Three buildings are actually going up here now and four or five families have had the ambition to get Wall Paper to decorate their houses. In some cases this Wall Paper had to be pasted on logs. It wasn't bad at that. I had the privilege to help some of them out in putting up this paper and develop a very sore back. They are quite proud of their work.

I don't want you to think, Mr. Hoey, that Grouard has become a Paradise, however. There is a lot of corruption among the people yet though these activities have helped to correct some of it. But I do hope that the Mounted Police will help me with some of the hopeless cases. In any case, there is a lot of work to do yet and it will take more than a year to do it. What really matters, I feel, is that we try to do it and do it the right way.

The Old Pupils miss Sister Jean a great deal. They simply won't accept the idea that she is not to come back. She was really one "of a thousand" as far as they were concerned and they have reasons to think this treatment is not fair. Herein, a copy of a letter sent to the Superior General of the Sisters of Providence. It speaks for itself.

Pardon me for being so lengthy...yet much more could be said.

Yours respectfully,

Rev. G. Forcade, O.M.I.
Dear Mother General,

As we look at our school now, it has already changed to something of the past. And yet only a short while ago did we gather at its doors to see our dear old teacher whose heart carried many of our secrets, and whose love smile did lift many a weary heart, whose words of encouragement guided many a faltering step back to God's hard and narrow road. To her, we could always go; but now when we do so we find we are heavy of heart, only emptiness greets us.

With this in mind, we, her old pupils come to you, to ask if she can't return in our midst. Many of us are spread distances apart, in these northern districts as well as elsewhere and therefore know that this place needs her badly. Not only for ourselves but also for the sake of the younger generation who need her guidance, as well as some of our own children who now attend our old school. This younger generation needs her guidance as in our day how the world is ever changing we want to see them be an honor to their school and God, and for that we need Sister Jean Placidus. For without her, things could not and will not be the same again ever.

Other sisters are very devoted and good in their own way, but Sister Jean, why, she has simply given her heart and soul into that work and understands so well, even the meanest can't help but be good, guided by her. She's given everything into all and everything that was concerned with the children. Even the singing in Church, you should just hear it now, it's a pity and a shame. The accompaniment for the singing, why even the best musician could not replace her. That reason is clear, she knows the children's singing and put her heart and soul into music and the children can't help but feel the effect. So we are now asking, begging you for the sake of these children, and our own to have her come back to our old school here.

Look at the wonderful work of the C.Y.O. The very beginning of its existence is nothing now but a memory. The souls and bodies of these children were changed in so short a time, through the C.Y.O., those who have been there before and after this came into life could easily see the change. What we need in our day and age is good clean recreation for the younger ones, that was only the beginning and look now nothing but a failure. After having endured so many hardships to get onto a good working scale, it is now all lost. We don't want only the memory of Sister Jean Placidus, we want her in person.

We cannot see these children plunge right in the turmoils of badness without good sound weapons with which to combat them. And these weapons are what they receive in school, and which they accept readily if they are encouraged by one they know has their confidence and their interest at heart. No matter how good a person is, they are confronted with evil every way they turn and for that reason they must have goodness implanted in their souls, encouragement and good guidance, by their teachers to prepare them to face hardships and shun evil after they leave this school.
Think also of all those old pupils far and wide, even in warring zones, who look forward to receive words of cheer and encouragement. They need that boosting of soul and spirit. Now where is that encouragement from her? Not from the old school as they would wish. Even so the Echoes keep on, it could never be the same, for Sister Jean is not at the helm. So we beg of you to consider this, and lend an ear to the plea of her old timers. Though not all can be present, their sole desire is this, that she may return to our old school.

We could keep on writing and writing, it could never be enough to give her credit, but we pray God daily to bring her back. For surely the work of a religious like her, especially in winning souls and bringing back strays to God are worth leaving where she can do most good and keep reaping, not only among the old timers, the younger people, but also among the peoples of this place and outlying districts. She's won their hearts and if by her kind words and works, bring these people to their church duties just when that was beating fruit, she had to leave.

So we hope that in the not far distant future our desire will be fulfilled. And when after this terrible war is over, some of her old timers who return and those who still live on may come back to a happy reunion with our dear friend and teacher Sister Jean Placidus, in our old school.

Sincerely, in the name of old timers,

(signed) Mrs. J.B.Ciroux.

Dear Mr. Greszchuk:

Your letter of November 15, 1943, was immediately following its receipt here, sent forward to the Departmental Solicitor.

I am today in receipt of a memorandum from the Solicitor, which reads in part as follows:

"The question submitted to the Department is difficult to answer and if answered at all must be in the broadest terms. An Indian living on the reserve is a denizen of the province in which he resides and has all the rights and liabilities of a white person. There are, of course, definite restrictions under the Indian Act where an Indian is living within a reserve.

"In so far as Paul Sound's children's school attendance is concerned it would seem that as he owns property in the town and it is assumed his taxes are paid, he should have the same school privileges as other property holders in the municipality. On the other hand it has been held in a British Columbia case that there is no duty cast upon a school board to receive within its schools children who are not resident within its own municipal district.

"As the question Mr. Greszchuk asks is one that deals with Alberta law it is not felt that any information which we can give him would be very helpful other than the statement that an Indian within the province has, for all practical purposes, the same rights as a white person."

Yours very truly,

When I was at Kinsao on the 5th of November 1943, I was consulted by one Paul Sound in connection with his right to send his children to the Kinsao School at Kinsao Alberta.

Mr. Sound informed me that he is a Treaty Indian but that he had purchased a lot in the town of Kinsao and intended to move to Kinsao. I understand that since that date Mr. Sound has moved in with his family to Kinsao but that the Kinsao school refuses to admit his children.

Since Mr. Sound no longer lives on the reserve and has purchased property in the town of Kinsao, it appears to me that he should have all the rights of a white person and that his children should be permitted to enter and attend the town school at Kinsao.

I know that the Dominion Government has established schools for the education of the Treaty Indians' children but since Mr. Sound no longer resides on the reserve but in the town of Kinsao, his children should be permitted to attend the town school.

I might say that I have written to the Department of Education at Edmonton and they take the stand by reason of the letter which you wrote to the Kinsao school or to Mr. James, the Indian Agent, that the provision of educational facilities for the children of Treaty Indians is the responsibility of the Ottawa Government, that the children of Paul Sound ought to be sent to the reserve school.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I had always hoped that I would be getting pictures of the new building and send them along to you when writing, but these have not come yet and I do not wish to delay any longer to give you news of our project.

The new building is nearly completed though very roughly. We had hoped to move in on the first anniversary of our Co-Operative, i.e., on the 1st of February, but we have been unable to do so. In the meantime, we are still working in the basement of the school where we operate our store. There are 6 women at work in the leathercrafts down here; they, as well as the employees in the construction of the building, are all old pupils. I remember your stressing the importance of employing old pupils and I did not think at the time that that would be possible but I find that it works out very much to your satisfaction. Five of the girls who are now working here were at school last year. When we get well started, we hope to be able to train girls who are presently at school. We are producing right now under very unfavourable circumstances. The new building will afford us a much better opportunity to produce. Our greatest difficulty then will be to find sufficient funds to get raw material.

At our meeting last Saturday the yearly financial report of the Co-Operative was given. As compared to the $15.00 with which we started last February, we find we now have assets to the amount of $5000. Our liabilities including shares amount to $870, leaving us a net credit balance of $1330. Nevertheless we are short of cash owing to the construction in progress. The people, however, are very satisfied and beginning to understand that they might be able to do something if they stick together, save and work. All in all things are going very well with them. It will be a very tough pull for some months until such time as we have enough capital to purchase stocks in sufficient quantities, and in due time with their comprehension of the work I hope we will be able to manage.

As soon as I do get pictures of the building, I shall send them on to you.

Thanking you once again for the very kind assistance you have given us, I remain,

yours truly,

Lake Agency, Alberta.

The above named has been a patient in this hospital
and is now discharged back to his home.

This boy originally arrived here when we first opened
the hospital in January, 1946, extremely ill with Advanced
Tuberculosis involving his lungs as well as his knee, leg and
arm. For a long time we thought that he was going to die,
but he eventually improved and we amputated his left leg above
the knee to get him back to normal. Since then he has done
very well and has remained well for the past eight months.

This boy is anxious to try to increase his educational
standard and, if possible, obtain clerical work. He roughly
has a grade six standing and it was indicated by the Provincial
Rehabilitation Officer who saw him that he would require at
least a grade eight before much could be done to help him.

We wondered if the Department in Ottawa would deem
it advisable to try to help this boy further his education and
give him training as a clerk so that he could carry on and earn
his own living in spite of his disability. If this cannot be
done this boy will be a public charge for the rest of his life
and it would be rather tragic to feel that we couldn't do some-
thing, at his age, to make him a worthwhile and respectable
Indian.

Anything that can be done for this boy will be very
much appreciated as he is a very likeable lad and has shown some
ambition which is to his credit.

This boy is, at present, back home at the Lesser Slave Lake Agency.

H. Meltsner, M.D.,

Dear Sir:

Am writing you today regarding the question of the children.

We can't seem to any arrangements with Fr. Tessier; so am making a direct appeal to you, and see if you can make some suitable arrangements for us. You can see any Father or person around here regards to us, if you wish. We are honest and decent people striving to make a home and living for our children.

Both my husband and myself are opposed to the children being put in the Mission. He seems to think it's the only way and insists on our putting the children in. First off, despite the material gain and understanding all advantages, we feel that the children's place is at home. We are not rich, 'tis true, but we've managed to keep the family together so far and our ambition is to build a good home and provide a good education for the children. The children attend school regularly, with the exception of days of illness. We are living right at the very doorstep of the Mission, and don't see any sense of being forced to put them in. If we were any distance away for the children's schooling we'd never hesitate putting them there; but this way I can't see any point in it.

If you wish you may come and see us. We live directly across from the Co-op in a big house. We'd be glad to see you.

Thanking you in advance.

Mr. J.B. Giroux, Treaty Indian #45, of the Swan River Band, makes his home on property not more than 300 yards from the Grouard Roman Catholic Indian Residential School. Mr. Giroux has three children of school age. According to Father Tessier, Principal, these children attended school for three years as day pupils and the school received no remuneration for tuition. Again this year Mr. Giroux wishes to have his children attend the Grouard School as day pupils but the principal is of the opinion that the school should receive payments for tuition.

I visited the Giroux home yesterday. The house is a frame building with insul-brick on the exterior. The interior is clean and well furnished. The Girouxs take much interest in their children's welfare, and the family life seems to be wholesome. The mother is well educated, as is shown by the enclosed copy of her letter which was written by Mrs. Giroux herself.

I recommend that the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, pay the Grouard R.C. Indian Residential School $1.50 per day for the tuition of the Giroux children; the above amount being from the scale of tuition payments which has been adopted by the provincial Department of Education. Father Tessier, principal of the school, has stated that such a payment would be satisfactory to him and I see no
why it should not be accepted by the Treasury branch, as it would, I believe, save funds.

I have made it clear to Mr. and Mrs. Giroux that my recommendation to the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, would depend upon home conditions. Should the tuition of the Giroux children be paid by the Department, an incentive would be furnished to the parents of the children, to improve their home.

G.S. Lapp,
Superintendent.

On May 4th 1948 we received an accountable advance of $500. for School Fuel. This was to be for the Peguis Schools, Fisher River and Jackhead. However, since installing 2 booker heaters at Peguis, and taking over the Schools on the Gypsumville line, where there is a Booker Heater, we will require additional funds to take care of the Booker Coal that will have to be purchased.

We estimate these Booker Heaters burn about a ton a month, and on this basis, we expect to require about 20 tons. The average laid down price runs around $8.00 for coal and about the same for delivery. The delivery price is high, as some of these roads are almost impassable for trucks, and coal may have to be hauled in with team.

It is expected here that we will require an additional advance of about $300.00 to take care of this item.

The Booker Heaters installed at the Peguis Schools are working satisfactorily. It appears they work better in cold weather.

We are pleased to acknowledge Mr. Neary's letter 42136-2 (El) of the 12th instant, advising that an additional advance of $300.00 is being forwarded to this Office for School Fuel, Peguis & Fisher River Reserves. The $500.00 forwarded last April has now been expended and a Credit Voucher is going forward covering this advance.

In connection with the $900.00 Fuel advance, this is for the Schools on the Gypsumville Line, and we have forwarded to Mr. Favelle, Assistant Indian Agency there, $250.00 for local purchase from the Indians. We still have a balance of $650.00 to forward to him as soon as he has expended the $250.00 already forwarded.

In passing, we wish to point out that Mr. Favelle is having difficulty in purchasing this fuel for the schools there, as this is the fishing season and the Indians are out on the Lakes fishing. He hopes to have this wood hauled in at the close of the fishing season about the end of January.

S Boyne

c.c. Mr. Davis, WINNIPEG.
Re Coal: #1, 2 and 3 Peguis Schools-

We wish to advise that the 2 Booker Heaters in Peguis #1 and #2 schools, and the furnace in Peguis #1, are burning more coal than we had anticipated, and that, we will need an additional advance to take care of fuel requirements until this spring.

10 Tons of Booker and 10 Tons of Lump coal have been purchased so far, but we have had to order more Booker coal. It is also expected that #1 Peguis School will require more lump coal this season.

As our Fuel account is about exhausted, and we have not purchased our regular wood fuel allowances for the other Peguis and Fisher River Schools, it is estimated that we will require another advance of $300.00 to carry us through this season.

Dear Mr. Davis,

Reference is made to fuel requirements at Peguis #1 School. This is the new school built last fall with a coal furnace.

This school started December 1946 and we have purchased to date, 10 tons drumheller. Mr. Boyne visited this school yesterday and advised that another 5 tons of coal would be required before the end of the week. This means that this furnace is burning nearly 5 tons a month.

This does not seem possible, and when the teacher Mr. Marsh was questioned, he advised that he was only firing in the usual way, and keeping the building moderately warm. The weather has been cold, but it appears excessive, that this furnace should burn so much coal.

We would be pleased if you would phone the Campbell Heating Company and ascertain from them the fuel requirements under ordinary use, for this furnace. It would appear that we will require a carload of coal for this furnace for one season.

Cheque #68449 dated November 18th 1949

This cheque was made in favour of Harry Fiddler on the Fuel Schools Account for sawing wood at Peguis #3 School in the amount of $8.00. Receipt #1608 was duly signed by him and the cheque given to him. The Fuel Schools Account was debited $8.00 and the corresponding entry recorded in the Agency Cash Book.

On receipt of the cancelled cheques from the Winnipeg office of the Bank of Montreal the usual procedure of reconciling the cancelled cheques with the cheque stubs was carried out in order to determine the Outstanding Cheques issued by the Agency and not yet cashed. On comparing the stub which was marked $8.00 with the cheque, it was disclosed that the cheque had been raised from the original figure $8.00 to $18.00 and the "eight" to "eighteen". The cheque has been endorsed by Harry Fiddler and Skibinski a merchant in Hodgson - it had also been passed to the Coco-Coal Company, who it is anticipated presented the cheque to the Bank of Montreal in Winnipeg.

The matter was reported to the Hodgson Detachment of the R.C.M.P. Constable Buchanan visited the Agency Office and examined the Cash Book, Ledger, Receipt Book, Cheque Stub and was given possession of the raised cheque #68449 for investigation purposes.

Ottawa, May 9th, 1947.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Manitoba.

Attached is a copy of a letter received from Miss Kathleen Jeffrey, teacher of the Peguis South School, complaining about the amount allowed her for janitor services.

Please let me have your comments on her letter and at the same time, you should return it.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

PP/MGD
April 21, I received a cheque for $10.50, Cheque No. BL224 for Janitor Service at South Region Indian Day School. I received a same cheque for December and one for $2.50 in September. This makes a total of $24.50.

We wish to acknowledge Mr B F Neary's letter 14-136 (WT 1) dated May 9th last, together with a letter received from Miss Kathleen Jeffrey, Teacher South Peguis School.

We note the contents of her letter, and advise that, we have been in the habit of paying Teachers $10.50 per quarter for Janitor services. For Fisher River School, we pay $24.00 per quarter.

It is of course, immaterial to us whether the teacher does the work or gets a pupil to do it. The rate, may be too low, but all schools at this Agency are paid at the above rate. However, we feel that $3.00 for oiling is high, while $6.00 per Month for sweeping, starting fires etc may be reasonable.

If Miss Jeffrey is to be paid extra, over and above the allowed rate, a revision of Janitor Services should be made to cover all the schools at this Agency.

As requested, Miss Jeffrey's letter is attached hereto.

I beg to recommend that a temporary position of Caretaker for the Fisher River Indian Day School be set up, for the period November 1st to April 30th each winter, at a salary of $60.00 per month, the duties to consist of firing the furnaces, cutting stove wood, sweeping out the two class rooms and entrance hall each day after school hours, and general care of the building.

This school is a large building, with two class rooms and residence. It is heated by two large furnaces which take a four foot stick of wood, and the work entailed is far too heavy for two women teachers, (Only one at present), as much of the wood used for the furnaces is tamarac and Spruce, many of the billets weighing anywhere from 50 to 100 pounds each. Last winter Mrs Scott actually became ill with having to do this work.

I have located an Indian who lives near the school, who would undertake this work at the above mentioned wages. Please advise by return mail if possible, if this recommendation is approved.

P.G. Lazerty,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, October 16, 1947.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby, Indian Agent,

Fisher River Indian Day School Caretaker

Reference your 7-E 15 October, 1947.

Any position which carries an annual salary in excess of $300.00 requires a Civil Service establishment for the position and the usual advertising, etc., for someone to fill the position.

Therefore it would be a long and involved process to establish a position such as you have described in your letter of October 15.

Bernard F. Heary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Fisher River Agency

Re: Fisher River Indian Day School Caretaker.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Mr. B.F. Neary's letter of the 18th instant, File 14-136 (W.T.) regarding the above noted subject.

In view of the fact that a position carrying a salary of more than $300.00 per annum requires a Civil Service Establishment, would it not be possible to engage the services of a Caretaker for this school for the five months from November to March next, inclusive, at $60.00 per month?

This would cover the greater part of the winter, and would relieve the teachers of the most of the heavy work of firing the furnaces. Please advise.

P.G. Lazenby,

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Manitoba.

We have your letter of the 24th ultimo with further reference to the amount requested for the caretaker at the Fisher River School.

Since writing to you on October 18th, there has been a change in the regulations by which any position which carries an annual salary in excess of $400, requires a Civil Service establishment for the position and the usual advertising, etc., for someone to fill the position.

In view of this decision, we are now in a position to allow a maximum amount of $400 a year for the caretaking services at the Fisher River School.

You might request the cooperation of the teacher by arranging to have the children sweep and dust class rooms and relieve the janitor of a certain amount of work. We feel that all parties concerned should cooperate in this matter. If our suggestion is followed out in the above regard, the amount of $400 a year for the janitor appears to us to be ample.

Bernard F. Henry

August 11, 1948.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Hodgson, Man.

We have your voucher No. 767 issued in favour of Mr. John Keeper, caretaker of the Murdoch School, during the month of July.

It is noted that you quote as authority for this expenditure official letter of January 13, 1948. If you refer to that letter you will realize that the authority given was intended for keeping the new building warm until a teacher had been appointed.

As the Murdoch school is now in operation, we feel that you should arrive at a satisfactory basis for the janitor services. Please let me know the amount that you suggest for this particular purpose and you might also state why you consider it necessary to submit a voucher for John Keeper for the month of July when the school was closed.

Bernard F. Henry
Superintendent of Education.

PP/MGD
We have for acknowledgement Mr. Neary's letter of the 11th instant file 14-136 (E 1) in connection with Voucher #767 in favour of John Keeper.

Mr. Keepar's services were retained for July to keep the grass down, look after the buildings and in general, keep track of hinges. Indians will break in and Mr. Keeper was held responsible for the Murdoch School.

Since the school has been opened, he has been retained getting the teacher established and doing chores around the place. The school now has to be scrubbed and swept regularly, besides other work, and it is thought that possibly, a man and his wife should be engaged for this work. The rate for each would probably have to be $20.00 each per month.

We trust the above voucher 767 can be approved in favour of Mr. Keeper, and would appreciate the Department's views in connection with the employing of a man and a woman for carrying on the work.

for P & Lazenby
SB, M
P. M.
Sup't Fisher River Agency

Reference is made to janitor services and salaries at Schools at this Agency. It appears that the teachers and any one who we try to hire for this work, complain that $10.50 per quarter is too low. We of course, pay $12.00 per month at Murdoch School, and $40.00 to Mr. Kirkness a month caring for the Fisher River School.

All the Peguis schools #2, 3, and 4 together with the three Peguis W.A. Halls as second rooms are in operation. However, we are having difficulty securing anyone to make fires, sweep and other duties at these Peguis Schools and Halls for $10.50 per three months. Some teachers do not want to take on the work at all especially, the women. To hire Indians at the above rate is out of the question.

We would be pleased to have the Department's comments regarding these salaries, and if an increase can be made, by return AIR MAIL, as we are carrying on presently best we can until this matter can be cleared up.

Mr. R.L. Bewell,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Hodgson, P.O., Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Bewell,

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo. File 7. Wherein you advice of the reduction in wages for janitor's services at No.1 school Fairford.

I am wondering if you are not confusing Lake St Martin school with No.1 school Fairford. The janitor or fireman at Lake St Martin school is paid at the rate of $1.00 per day, previously the rate of pay for janitor's services at Fairford No.1 school was fixed at $25.00 per month. However, after the rise in the cost of living, this amount was considered insufficient and the rate was increased to $30.00 per month.

I feel that the cut in wages as well as the cut in services to the teacher would result in so much dissatisfaction both to Mrs. Olds and the janitor that the savings derived therefrom, would not be sufficient to compensate for the unfriendly feeling it would create.

I would suggest, if I may, that the present arrangements be carried through until the end of the current school year and a new scale of wages worked out for the next term.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
R.F. Traveller,
Gypsumville, P.O., Manitoba.

Re: Caretaker Fairford #1 School

Since school opened this term we have had no end of trouble with the caretaker of the above school who was Solvie Letander.

I would like to have authority to Voucher for $30.00 per month for Mr. D.J. Olds as caretaker for the above school. His duties will be to clean and put on storm windows in the fall. Re: Fairford #1 Indian Day School

We are in receipt of a letter from Acting Superintendent D.A.H. Nield requesting authority to allow D.J. Olds $30.00 as caretaker of the above school. Mr. Nield describes Mr. Olds' duties as follows:

"His duties will be to clean and put on storm windows in the fall. Remove and put on screens in the spring. Scrub the classroom once a month and clean and empty toilets when necessary. Get in wood for furnace and keep classroom warm."

The rate suggested is higher than we have been allowing, and if we give favourable consideration to the Superintendent's recommendation in this particular instance, will it involve increasing the rates for janitor service at other schools in that Agency and possibly in other Agencies in Manitoba.

Please let me have your comments on the recommendation.

Philip Phelan,
PP/ST Chief, Education Division

I enclose herewith copies of statements of accountable advances at the Babine Agency during 1946-47. The original was returned with the Receiver General payment covering the total of balances outstanding.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6488, file 42151-2, part 4)
The above two-roomed school is at present being taught by Mr. R. Woollam (senior Room) and Mr. L. Leighton who are living together in the Mission House at Kispiox and in their absence during school hours there is nobody to keep the fires going. They have asked me if I can supply them with 3 tons of coal at a cost of $15 per ton.

There does not seem to be any clear definition of Departmental policy in this respect but I have been in the habit of permitting teachers to make use of school fuel in their residences in view of the hitherto inadequate salaries. In this case Mr. Woollam is receiving $1260 p.a., and Mr. Leighton $1000 and I would recommend that we might supplement this by offering these young men their coal and light. I have already given them some wood but this of course will not keep the fires in during their absence and I would suggest that a small supply of coal, not exceeding 3 tons be made available at their residence; also a supply of Gasoline or Coal Oil for lighting. Will you kindly let me know your decision in this matter.

J.W. Boys
Indian Agent.

I enclose herewith original and copy of Day School Return received from W.H.R. Low, Esq., Secretary of the Walcott Day School at Telkwa, B.C., covering the attendance of six children of the Moricetown Band, for the quarter ending December 31st, 1945, and to advise that the Secretary verbally requested of me, the usual remuneration to the board for the tuition of these children.

The Dennis children, numbers 1, 2, 3 & 6 are those of Michell Dennis, who spends a great deal of his time with his son at Walcott where he is employed as a Section Man. They attended the Moricetown Indian Day School quite regularly when a teacher was available, but since that school is closed they have continued their education at Walcott, and it would appear to be no question of the Department's position in making the payment requested for them, which I recommend.

The children, numbers 4 & 5, are those of Tommy Joseph (Round Lake Tommy) who has not lived continuously on any Moricetown Reserve for ten or fifteen years, but has resided and operated a farm on Provincial lands near Telkwa, returning to the Reserve only for fishing during the Salmon run, in the late summer. The question arises as to the Department's responsibility for the education of the children of an Indian not residing on a Reserve, although presumably as he continues to be carried on our census, we have some obligation in the matter of the education of the children, and your views of the matter would be appreciated.

It will be noted that the children did not commence the fall term until October. The reason being that the trustees were unable to engage the services of a teacher until that month.
If the application receives favourable consideration, cheque should be mailed to W.H.R. Low, Esq., Secretary, Walcott School Board, Telkwa, B.C.

MEMORANDUM.

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.
From: Inspector of Indian Schools.

I refer to the application of Mr. Indian Agent Boys for tuition grants for the ensuing academic year for Walter Harris, Doreen Harris and Mary Johnson of the Kispiox Band.

It is noted in the covering letter from Mr. Boys that the mother of the Harris children will be living in a rented house in Prince Rupert. Under these circumstances tuition fees should not be charged against these pupils in keeping with Mr. Neary's letter dated May 23, 1947, in which it was stated -

"The Department have never assumed responsibility for education of Indian children in elementary grades when the parents reside in a municipality and are either house owners or tenants. We have always considered that in such cases they are entitled to the same consideration as any other resident of the Municipality."

Although the reference is to "elementary pupils" only, it is assumed that the same principle applies to High School pupils. This will reduce the total per capita cost from $500 to $400 for the two Harris children.

It appears that the parents have made this arrangement in order to provide an education for their children, and I consider that their effort merits support. I recommend that approval be given to a per capita grant of $200 for Walter and Doreen Harris.

Tuition fees are assessable against Mary Johnson and I recommend that the request for a grant of $250 for this pupil be approved.

R.F. Davey
Inspector of Indian Schools.

The method of payment requested by the School District No. 54, Smithers, is new and considerably higher than the rate we have previously allowed.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Your file 103-151-(E.1)
Re: Tuition Fees for Indian Pupils Attending Provincial Schools

I refer to Mr. Phelan's letter of March 20th concerning the above. I feel that it would not be desirable to have the matter of tuition fees reviewed with the Department of Education in Victoria.

At the beginning of the current academic year Inspector Davey called upon the Deputy Minister of the Department of Education for B.C. with regard to other matters and on this occasion the Minister of his own initiative brought up this matter and expressed the opinion that our Department should assume the full cost for the education of Indian children in Provincial schools. He was not aware apparently that the present rate of $35.00 a year for elementary pupils was an amount found satisfactory by the Trustees Association of B.C. in 1945. He maintained that since education of Indian children was the responsibility of the Dominion Government our Department should bear the total cost and that the present grant of $35.00 a year was most inadequate. In support of this he produced the Public School Reports for several years showing that the present cost of educating children in the Provincial schools was in excess of $100.00 per year.

At the present time the highest grant paid by the
Department to any school board in B.C. for elementary education is $65.00 per pupil per year. This represents the total cost less the Provincial grant.

It is suggested that in those cases where a school board requests the payment of tuition fees amounting to the per capita cost the Department meet this request and that the School Board concerned be asked to submit with their account a break down of these costs.

It might be pointed out that the Provincial School Act requires that a School District shall not charge another School District for tuition fees in excess of the difference between the actual cost and the Provincial grants. This is a new section of the Act and has given rise to the form used in the case of the children of Mitchell Dennis.

Your further comment on this matter will be appreciated.

W.S. Arneil,

Re Credit Vouchers nos. 325 and 326 for Walter and Doreen Harris, Kispiox Band, Babine Agency. These youngsters discontinued their studies at Prince Rupert High School at Christmas time. They both made splendid progress and the Principal spoke in high praise of both pupils.

October 20, 1948

Mr. J. V. Boys  
Superintendent Babine Agency  
Hazelton, B. C.

Dear Mr. Boys:

Your letter to the burser of the Sim Seminary of Christ the King was sent to me.

As I recall I asked Mr. Anfield last year for a grant to cover one hundred dollars that I paid for Kenneth Harris in the scholastic year 1947/48 as well as for three hundred dollars for the current scholastic year. At the time he did not give me much hope that the one hundred dollar account would be paid and, if I must, I accede to the department's decision.

Now the fees for 1948/49 have been increased to $350.00 and I would ask you if you would kindly re-submit the request for a grant for the entire amount. It would be strange if the Department, in view of the present high cost of living, considered $350.00 too much for board, room and tuition. Personally I find the fifty dollar increase over last year entirely justified.

Thank you very much for your interest in this matter.

Kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) A. JORDAN, O.M.I.

Most Rev. Anthony Jordan, O.M.I.  
Vicar Apostolic of Prince Rupert

P.S. I'll be home on Nov. 17th.

His Excellency's letter explains the discrepancy.

I would recommend that a grant of $350.00 be afforded for the current year.

J.V. BOE

AGREEMENT

AGREEMENT made this Fifteenth Day of September, A.D., 1949

BETWEEN

HIS MAJESTY KING GEORGE THE SIXTH
in right of Canada, represented herein
by the Minister of Mines and Resources,
hereinafter called the "Minister"

- and -

THE SCHOOL DISTRICT No. 53 (Terrace)
in the Province of British Columbia,
hereinafter called the "School District
No. 53 (Terrace).

WHEREAS the Minister is obliged under the present circum-
stances to build adequate school accommodation for the Indian children of
the Hazelton Indian reserve;

AND WHEREAS the School District No. 53 (Terrace) are pre-
paring to build adequate school accommodation for the White children of
Hazelton;

AND WHEREAS surveys made by the Minister and the School
District No. 53 (Terrace) would indicate the desirability of amalgamating
these two racial groups;

AND WHEREAS the ratepayers in the Hazelton attendance area
of School District No. 53 (Terrace) have approved by an affirmative vote
such an amalgamation;

AND WHEREAS the amalgamation of these two racial groups would
work for the benefit of both in making possible the provision of better faci-
lities, staff and school accommodation;

AND WHEREAS the financial assistance agreed upon in the terms
herein mentioned is considered fair and reasonable;

AND WHEREAS surveys indicate that the ratio of attendance
would be nine Indian children to seven White children;

AND WHEREAS the School District No. 53 (Terrace) estimates
the cost of this structure will be approximately One Hundred and Thirty
Thousand Dollars ($130,000.00) including full furnishings;

AND WHEREAS the Minister would be asked to provide nine-
sixteenth of this amount, or an amount of Seventy-three Thousand Dollars
($73,000.00) leaving an amount of Fifty-seven Thousand Dollars ($57,000.00)
to be provided by the School District No. 53 (Terrace);

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6488, file 42151-3, part 1)

AND WHEREAS the Department of Education will provide an amount of Twenty-eight Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($28,500.00);

AND WHEREAS the School District No. 33 (Terrace) will provide an amount of Twenty-eight Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($28,500.00);

NOW THIS AGREEMENT witnesseth that the parties hereto mutually covenant and agree as follows:

1. This agreement shall commence on the first day of January, 1930 and shall be subject to the terms, conditions and stipulations hereinafter expressed, that is to say:

2. The Minister shall pay the School District No. 33 (Terrace) an amount of Seventy-three Thousand Dollars ($73,000.00) which sum represents nine-twentieths of the estimated expenditure for the establishment of an amalgamated Senior High Elementary school building fully furnished;

3. The Minister shall pay the School District No. 33 (Terrace) tuition fees for the Indian children in attendance, in accordance with the provisions of Section 133 "Public Schools Act" of the Province of British Columbia.

4. The School District No. 33 (Terrace) shall render each quarter to the Minister a statement of the tuition fees to be paid; This statement shall be in the form as prescribed by section 133, "Public Schools Act" of the Province of British Columbia.

5. It is understood and agreed upon between the parties hereto that neither the execution of this agreement, nor anything contained herein, nor the expenditure of any funds hereunder by His Majesty in right of Canada shall be deemed to confer upon the Minister or any officer or Department of the Government of Canada any right of supervision or control over any school or educational institution operated by the School District No. 33 (Terrace), with respect to which any funds are expended under this agreement, nor any supervision or control over the administrative or teaching personnel or the curriculum or the methods of instruction or the materials of instruction of any such school or educational institution.

6. The Minister shall endeavor to maintain a standard of health, cleanliness and clothing among these Indian pupils such as would be comparable to that of White children attending the school.

Dear Sir,

re- Janitor Services, Kitwaneoool School.

I am in receipt of an enquiry from Mrs. J. Chapman, teacher, regarding an allowance for janitor services at the Kitwaneoool Indian Day School.

When the late teacher, the Rev. Norman Green, was at Kitwaneoool the Department considered that his salary of $100.00 per teaching month was sufficient to cover the cost of janitor services, but as Mrs. Chapman receives only $85.00 per teaching month, I would ask that an amount of $6.00 per month be allowed for janitor services at the Kitwaneoool school as is allowed other one-roomed schools in this Agency.

Yours faithfully,

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

March 10, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I would recommend consideration of the application at the rate of $5.00 per month.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKey,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
