Dear Sir,

I am writing to you in regards to the following:

I received all janitor cheques up to date from September 1st to December 1943 except the one for the scrubbing of the mission school which I had done twice from Sept to December by an Indian woman. The amount is $6.00 for each time the school is scrubbed, amount being $12.00. I should like to know if this cheque had been sent to me or if it was sent direct.

With reference to Mr. Phelan's note attached to the enclosed letter—which is being returned as requested—I wish to advise that Mrs. Buddrus was informed at the time she commenced duties as teacher of the Moricetown Indian Day School that she would receive an allowance of $6.00 per school month for janitor services. Although scrubbing of the school floor was not specifically mentioned, it was presumed that Mrs. Buddrus would have accepted this as part of the janitor services as teachers have done in all other schools of this Agency. She received a cheque for $6.00 for September which should have been sufficient evidence of the monthly payment for this work. I have received one letter from Mrs. Buddrus, who has been advised in this matter when the subject was discussed some two weeks ago.

During the time the last teacher was at Moricetown, the Indians took advantage of her generosity in this regard and I am certain she paid more to them than she herself received. I did not know that anything like $6.00 was paid for scrubbing a floor, which could be done in under 4 hours.

S. Mallinson
Indian Agent

Ottawa,
April 5, 1944.

EX'D.

Dear Madam:

I have your letter of the 13th ultimo, requesting payment for scrubbing the Moricetown School.

Scrubbing the school is considered part of the janitor's duties and an amount of $6 a month is allowed for this service and has been paid to you. Our reason for giving it to the teacher is that in practice we find that such procedure gives the teacher more control over the janitor than if the amount were paid directly to the janitor. In view of the fact that scrubbing the school is considered part of the janitor's duties, there is no further payment due you.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mrs. A.C. Buddrus,
Teacher,
Moricetown Indian Day School,
Smithers, B.C.

February 5th, 1945.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver,

In reply to your letter above noted I wish to submit herewith a letter received from the Principal of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School regarding the work of Edward Elliott, caretaker of the building, and which I trust you will find self explanatory. To this I would like to add the following:

1. This man is giving good satisfaction in his work, the amount he does and how he does it.

2. I believe that he will improve even more, not so much in the way he does the work but rather in little savings here and there. He certainly takes an interest in the school.

3. Insofar as recommending Elliott's retention in office is concerned, I believe that so long as we employ an Indian for the position I feel that we will never get a more satisfactory one.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

Duncan, B.C.
February 5th, 1945.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

In reply to your letter above noted I wish to submit herewith a letter received from the Principal of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School regarding the work of Edward Elliott, caretaker of the building, and which I trust you will find self explanatory. To this I would like to add the following:

1. This man is giving good satisfaction in his work, the amount he does and how he does it.

2. I believe that he will improve even more, not so much in the way he does the work but rather in little savings here and there. He certainly takes an interest in the school.

3. Insofar as recommending Elliott's retention in office is concerned, I believe that so long as we employ an Indian for the position I feel that we will never get a more satisfactory one.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

CONFIDENTIAL.
St. Catherine's Indian School,
Duncan, B.C.,
February 5, 1948.

Mr. R. H. Moore, Indian Agent,
Indian Office,
Duncan, B.C.

Dear Mr. Moore,

Referring to your letter of the 19th ultimo and in answer to your enquiries regarding a report on the services rendered by Edward Elliot as Caretaker of St. Catherine's School, I beg to state:

(1) He gives satisfaction in the fulfillment of the duties assigned, and there is plenty of work to keep him employed in and around the building.

(2) My opinion of his increasing in efficiency is a peculiar question to answer as any man may become more efficient in any line of work with each day's effort.

(3) I still maintain that it would never be advisable to hire an Indian permanently. Once they feel secure, that is the time their efficiency ceases. A yearly basis is the better arrangement.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

D.M. MacKay,

RE: Agency Voucher No. 1050 (1947)

Kindly refer to your 14-151-E4 of May 15th, 1948 concerning payment of $24.00 for Janitor Services from Sept. 1st to Dec. 31st, 1947 to Miss N. Skaftfeld, teacher at the Kitwancool Indian Day School. We have informed Miss Skaftfeld that this account was paid by your cheque No. 24117 of January 12th, 1948 but Miss Skaftfeld replies that this cheque was never received.

With reference to Agency Voucher No.192 amounting to $2.00, Janitor Service at the Katzic Indian Day School, dated from here on the 17th of June last.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Major D.H. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

Mr. George Fellowes, Teacher at the Skwah Indian Day School, has asked that the Janitor Fee of $5.00 a month, be increased to $10.00.

He claims that it is difficult to get anyone to scrub the School for the amount available, after he has paid the children various sums for sweeping and putting fires on.

I would recommend that the Janitor Fee be increased to $10.00 a month, beginning from the first of January, 1947.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

I am forwarding a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Gillett concerning an increase in janitor fees for the Skwah Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency.

In view of the fact that the matter of janitor fees was recently considered by the Department and a schedule of $6.00 per month has been set for one room schools in the Skeena River Agency I cannot recommend that an increase be granted in this case where the duties of a janitor are less onerous.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, 21 January 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, it is considered that $6.00 a month is sufficient to allow for janitor fees at the Skwah Indian Day School.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of October 7th regarding a cheque for janitor service for month of June for Bristle School. Janitor services includes putting on fires, sweeping, dusting, scrubbing, etc. Putting on fires, sweeping, and dusting takes 1/2 hours per day. For 200 school days labor would amount to 300 hours. This would be 37 1/2 days of 8 hours each. Then the school gets a general cleaning every two months. There is practically nothing left for the other work until the school is scrubbed.

I would refer you to article #51, School closes for the Summer holidays in the Indian School Bulletin of June 1st, 1948. "Please leave your school in a spotless clean condition."

In this bulletin I am advised to leave the school clean then from the same department I am advised that there is no money to be paid for this work.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6489, file 42153-6, part 3)

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
If there was no scrubbing etc. to do the wages for the other work would amount to $1.60 per day for an eight-hour day but after allowing wages for scrubbing the wages drops almost to 80 cents per day. I tell you Mr. Philcox it is next to impossible to get any party to work for such low wages. I am informed that in many of the Indian Schools wages for janitor services is much higher and I should suggest to you that the wages here would be stepped up.

I feel that it is beneath the dignity of a Department of the Dominion Government to quibble over the small amount involved. I shall expect my cheque by return of mail and also ask you to give consideration to make the stipend higher.

Yours Truly,
Fred C. Monaghan
